title: Object injection in `stripe-billing-typographic` GitHub project via /auth/login

profile.name: Stripe
profile.about: Stripe is a technology company that builds economic infrastructure for the internet.

vulnerability_information:
## Summary:
It is possible to use an object injection failure to achieve a sql injection, where attacker uses the means to bypass authentication, requiring only a valid password within the database.

The vulnerable code is:  https://github.com/stripe/stripe-billing-typographic

For a failure to occur, it is necessary that the environment is configuring with the mysql database.  

The same scenario is seen in the demonstration environment: https://typographic.io/

## Steps To Reproduce:

  1. Register a simple user in the application, with a password at your desire. Ex:
```
user: test@test.com
password:123
```
  2. Send a request to /auth/login like this:
```
POST /auth/login

{"email":{"email":1},"password":"1234"}
```
  3. You will then see that the login was performed without the need to provide a valid user!

{F1287585}


## Supporting Material/References:
Well, the failure occurs due to the possibility of an object reaching the query, which will be handled by a dependency called sqlstring, performing some scapes, where it will cause a confusion to the query.

Sqlstring will handle {,} replacing with `. 
So your login query will be:
```
SELECT * FROM `accounts` WHERE `email`=`email`=1
```
The sql string library is a dependency on the mysql library, which is used by knex.

## Mitigation

Is a simple step, use JSON.stringfy e resolve your problem, because JSON.stringfy will transform the malicious object into a string, preventing treatment during a query.

## Impact

This vulnerability to the applied scenario makes it easier for the attacker to acquire accounts, as the attacker only needs to discover a valid password to gain access to the victim's account.

activities.message:
Sorry, the correct second step is:

2- Send a request to /auth/login like this:
```
POST /auth/login

{"email":{"email":1},"password":"123"}
```

Regards,
@phor3nsic

Hi @phor3nsic,

Thank you for your submission. I hope you are well. Your report is currently being reviewed and the HackerOne triage team will get back to you once there is additional information to share.

Have a great day! 

Kind regards,
@orangeband

Hey @phor3nsic

Something appears to be off here. So I have created a test account and using just the password and your request, I was able to generate the token. However, when I asked another triager to create test creds and was given the password, it **did not** work. Additionally, your creds also didn't work using this method. Is there a reason as to why some of these would work but others wouldn't?

Thank you,
@orangeband

Hello @orangeband, Do you have any questions?
Allow me to help you! :)

Regards,
@phor3nsic

Hi @magicmouse,
Possibly your error occurred due to the lack of content-type in the header!
Try this:
```
curl -X 'POST' -H "Host: http://localhost:3000/" -i -s -k --data '{"email":{"email":1},"password":"1234"}' http://localhost:3000/auth/login -H "Content-type: application/json"
```

Regards,
@phor3nsic
Hi @magicmouse, did you manage to do the procedures?

Hi @turtle_shell, @magicmouse and @orangeband, please read a description, this a simple steps, the application remains vulnerable. The last commit was January 14th, there is no reason for such a question.

I redone the clone and installation of the application, the process and the same. It's Vulnerable!

Please don't change more triagers !

And if necessary, please reread the steps.

Here is another proof and the curl command to make the process easier, and the config file that should be used for the mysql environment:
{F1308665}

CURL
```
curl -i -s -k -X $'POST' \
    -H $'Host: localhost:3000' -H $'Content-Type: application/json;charset=UTF-8' -H $'Content-Length: 40' \
    --data-binary $'{\"email\":{\"email\":1},\"password\":\"12345\"}' \
    $'http://localhost:3000/auth/login'
```

Config file:
{F1308671}

Video POC:
{F1288864}

**Please hackerone team, more attention!**

@phor3nsic
Hi @turtle_shell, could confirm that it is connected to the bd on mysql??

Hi @turtle_shell , I can confirm that this has already been mentioned, for this reason I expressed my indignation with the treatment on the part of the team!

```
Config local server
1- Clone the repository:
https://github.com/stripe/stripe-billing-typographic.git
2- To use the mysql environment as demonstrated in the report:
Replace the config.js file with: config.js (F1288818)
Edit the connection fields so you can be connected to your mysql server.
Note: This file was modified only the connection model, which for demonstration comes with sqllite, we will use mysql
3- Follow the steps in https://github.com/stripe/stripe-billing-typographic#getting-started
```

The error you have appears to be due to mysql credentials, change the fields that are with 
"// CHANGE_THIS".


```
Hold on, why should a victim change the config.js?
```
The change can be made if the client wants to use another database as the application supports with the use of knex and already has the mysql dependency by default.

This can be confirmed in package.json!

But understand, the problem consists of injecting objects, and this led to the query in the case of mysql can result in a sql injection

An example of use, and the application demonstration environment itself:
typographic.io
hi @turtle_shell, you have made progress?
Hi @wearehackerone updates???

For help triagers:
https://gccybermonks.com/posts/obji2sqli/

Hi @magicmouse, Thanks for you return, yes it is still possible to explore this issue!
{F1318136}

_Note:
In the demonstration environment, it is possible that there are some errors at times, as I believe that the database suffers some deletions, but as already demonstrated, whenever possible I managed to carry out the exploration_

As a help, I leave the link of my research:
https://gccybermonks.com/posts/obji2sqli/

Thanks
@phor3nsic

additional_data.new_title: Object injection in `stripe-billing-typographic` GitHub project via /auth/login

activities.message:
Hello @phor3nsic,

Thank you for your submission! We were able to validate your report, and have submitted it to the appropriate remediation team for review. They will let us know the final ruling on this report, and when/if a fix will be implemented. Please note that the status and severity are subject to change.

Regards,
@antenna

Hi @phor3nsic, 
Thank you very much for your report. We were able to reproduce the issue that you have outlined and are working on a fix. Please sit tight and we'll get back to you when we have an update!
Best,
@grazingllama

Hi @grazingllama , I hope you are alright!
Thank you very much for the quick response.
However, I have a question regarding the criticality applied by the other triage, applied as bass.
I believe this was designed because of the reproduction difficulties they had.
According to CVSS this is rated as High (7.4)

CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:H

Let me know what you think about this report,
Have a nice Day!
@phor3nsic :)

Hi @phor3nsic,

The severity is based on the following:
> {F1329225}
> An attacker can perform login requests as the first user created on the web server, without knowing their username/email
> > Attacker would still have to guess/know the first created user's password to login as them

Best regards,
@antenna

Hi @antenna, I hope you are alright!
But when accessing the victim's account, we have a broken confidentiality and we can simply change data such as password and user, thus reaching the victim's account availability as integrity, as changes were made.

Thanks,
@phor3nsic

Hi @phor3nsic,

We've discussed this internally and have decided not to fix the issue for the following reasons:
1. Only the first user in the database is affected, and the attacker needs to know that user's password to perform the attack.
2. The vulnerability requires a non-default configuration.
3. The instance at https://typographic.io is a demo which contains no sensitive data.
4. Both the live demo and associated code are out of scope for our program (from our policy page, about our open source projects: "Only non-archived and non-demo/non-sample projects are in scope").

That said, given the technically interesting nature of your submission, we'd like to close this report as "Resolved" and award a bounty to encourage future participation in our program! Thank you for your help in keeping Stripe secure, and we look forward to receiving more reports from you in the future.

Best,
@grazingllama

Hi team,
I hope you are ok!

Please disclosure just the follow topics:
- Summary
- Steps To Reproduce
- Supporting Material/References

Have a nice day :)
\- @phor3nsic

Before we begin the disclosure process, wed like to provide you information about our process.

Like many companies, Stripe currently has a process for only limited disclosure via HackerOne. Per [our program terms](https://hackerone.com/stripe?type=team#user-content-terms-and-conditions), we ask that you limit disclosure to only the contents to be inserted into the public HackerOne report. Also, please be aware that either party may revoke or decline the disclosure request at any time.

Before disclosing the report via HackerOne, we would like to:

1. Verify report metadata (report title, severity, weakness, etc).
2. Provide a summary of the report if the issue is considered high or critical severity after metadata is verified

For the report metadata, we will make adjustments at our discretion but please let us know if you have any concerns about our adjustments.

If the issue is high or critical severity, we will draft a report summary for your review. Once both parties agree to the summary, we will add the summary to the report, [lock the final report](https://docs.hackerone.com/programs/locking-reports.html) to prevent changes, and then disclose the report. If you have any follow up comments after disclosure about this report, please open another report on HackerOne with Disclosure Followup in the title.

Please let us know if this sounds good to you and we can proceed with the next steps!

Hi @grazingllama, I have one similar post explained the vulnerability `object injection to sql injection`, if the program agree, i can ocult the content of this report and use my post to disclosure.

My post is:
https://gccybermonks.com/posts/obji2sqli/

This post not reference the Strip, but this report could be the reference.

Let me know if this is a good idea or not,
Have a good day,
@phor3nsic

We can either fully disclose this report, or cancel the disclosure request and you can just use your current blog post as the disclosure instead if you'd like. Let us know what you prefer.
Thanks,
@grazingllama

Hi @grazingllama,

I agree in disclosure this report...

Have a nice day!
